Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding the response of a natural system to long-term acidification using Sydney rock oysters and mud crabs as a model predator-prey system
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ocean acidification is the gradual decrease in ocean pH as a result of carbon dioxide (CO2) uptake, and it is expected to have detrimental effects on the shell formation of calcified organisms such as oysters. The effect of ocean acidification on multiple interacting species should be explored to understand impacts on ecosystem dynamics. Mangrove estuaries experiencing acidic soil runoff near Sydney, Australia provide a natural laboratory for the study of ocean acidification and its effects on the ecosystem. This study will examine the effect of ocean acidification on a crab-oyster predator-prey system through a caging experiment and a laboratory experiment using a natural population of oysters that have been exposed to acidification for generations. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Melanie Bishop, an expert on community ecology of mangrove invertebrates, at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia.

In the source estuaries, Sydney rock oysters (Saccostrea glomerata) grown in either acidified or normal pH conditions will be enclosed in cages with mud crab predators (Scylla serrata) in both acidified and normal pH water for one week. The relationship between oyster mortality, the presence of mud crabs, and pH will be examined using linear models. In a separate laboratory experiment, oysters from acidified and normal pH sites will be exposed to mud crab predation, and video of predator behavior will be used to calculate handling time (the time a predator spends manipulating or eating a prey item). The effect of acidification on handling time and oyster mortality will be examined using ANOVAs. This study expands upon ocean acidification research by examining the effect of global change on interactions between two commercially important species, and by using oysters that have had generations to adapt to long-term acidification in nature. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean acidification is the gradual decrease in ocean pH as a result of CO2 uptake, and it is expected to have detrimental effects on the shell formation of calcified organisms such as oysters. The effect of ocean acidification on multiple interacting species should be explored to understand impacts on ecosystem dynamics. Mangrove estuaries experiencing acidic soil runoff near Sydney, Australia provide a natural laboratory for the study of ocean acidification and its effects on the ecosystem. This study examined the effect of acidification on (1) oyster mortality, (2) the communities of animals that live on oyster clumps, and (3) the interaction between oysters and a large predatory crab through a field experiment and a laboratory experiment using a natural population of oysters that have been exposed to acidification for generations. This research was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Melanie Bishop, an expert on community ecology of mangrove invertebrates, at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia.

 

In the source estuaries, Sydney rock oysters (Saccostrea glomerata) grown in either acidified or normal pH conditions were transplanted to both acidified and normal pH water for two weeks. The relationship between oyster mortality, pH, and alkalinity were examined using linear models. In addition, oyster clumps were taken back to the lab and all of the organisms on the clumps were identified and counted. We examined the differences between the communities of animals living on oyster clumps that were transplanted to acidic sites and the communities on clumps that were in control, non-acidified conditions. In a separate laboratory experiment, oysters from acidified and normal pH sites were exposed to mud crab (Scylla serrata) predation, and video of predator behavior was used to calculate handling time (the time a predator spends manipulating or eating a prey item). The effect of acidification on handling time and oyster mortality was examined using linear models. This study expands upon ocean acidification research by examining the effect of global change on interactions between two commercially important species, and by using oysters that have had generations to adapt to long-term acidification in nature. This NSF EAPSI award was funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.


Last Modified: 02/19/2015
Modified by: Cassandra N Glaspie
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Ocean acidification is the gradual decrease in ocean pH as a result of CO2 uptake, and it is expected to have detrimental effects on the shell formation of calcified organisms such as oysters. The effect of ocean acidification on multiple interacting species should be explored to understand impacts on ecosystem dynamics. Mangrove estuaries experiencing acidic soil runoff near Sydney, Australia provide a natural laboratory for the study of ocean acidification and its effects on the ecosystem. This study examined the effect of acidification on (1) oyster mortality, (2) the communities of animals that live on oyster clumps, and (3) the interaction between oysters and a large predatory crab through a field experiment and a laboratory experiment using a natural population of oysters that have been exposed to acidification for generations. This research was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Melanie Bishop, an expert on community ecology of mangrove invertebrates, at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia. In the source estuaries, Sydney rock oysters (Saccostrea glomerata) grown in either acidified or normal pH conditions were transplanted to both acidified and normal pH water for two weeks. The relationship between oyster mortality, pH, and alkalinity were examined using linear models. In addition, oyster clumps were taken back to the lab and all of the organisms on the clumps were identified and counted. We examined the differences between the communities of animals living on oyster clumps that were transplanted to acidic sites and the communities on clumps that were in control, non-acidified conditions. In a separate laboratory experiment, oysters from acidified and normal pH sites were exposed to mud crab (Scylla serrata) predation, and video of predator behavior was used to calculate handling time (the time a predator spends manipulating or eating a prey item). The effect of acidification on handling time and oyster mortality was examined using linear models. This study expands upon ocean acidification research by examining the effect of global change on interactions between two commercially important species, and by using oysters that have had generations to adapt to long-term acidification in nature. This NSF EAPSI award was funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science. Last Modified: 02/19/2015 Submitted by: Cassandra N Glaspie
